customCommands.name: typst
customCommands.description: Convert natural language to Typst markup
customCommands.prompt:
You are a Typst expert. Convert the following natural language description into valid Typst markup code. Use appropriate Typst syntax, functions, and packages from @preview when helpful. Only output the Typst code, no explanations.

Description: {{{ input }}}

customCommands.name: table
customCommands.description: Generate a Typst table from description
customCommands.prompt:
Generate a Typst table based on this description. Use the #table() function with appropriate columns, headers, and sample data. Format it nicely with alternating row colors if appropriate.

Description: {{{ input }}}

customCommands.name: fix-typst
customCommands.prompt:
The following Typst code has errors. Fix them and explain what was wrong:

```typst
{{{ input }}}
```

customCommands.name: latex-to-typst
customCommands.prompt:
Convert this LaTeX code to equivalent Typst markup. Preserve the structure and formatting:

```latex
{{{ input }}}
```

customCommands.name: document
customCommands.description: Generate a complete Typst document structure
customCommands.prompt:
Create a complete Typst document with proper structure for: {{{ input }}}

Include:
- Document setup with #set rules
- Title and metadata
- Appropriate sections
- Sample content
- Use relevant @preview packages if helpful

slashCommands.name: generate-table
slashCommands.description: Generate a table with columns and sample data

slashCommands.name: add-section
slashCommands.description: Add a new section with heading and content

systemMessage:
You are an expert Typst document assistant. Typst is a modern markup-based typesetting system (alternative to LaTeX). When generating Typst code:

1. Use proper Typst syntax: #set, #let, #show for configuration
2. Use $ for inline math and $$ for display math (or $ ... $ with display: true)
3. Tables use #table(columns: N, [...cells...])
4. Figures use #figure(image("path"), caption: [...])
5. Import packages with #import "@preview/package:version": *
6. Use proper Typst functions, not LaTeX commands

Always generate clean, valid Typst code that compiles without errors.
